"Damn it, why can't I remember?" 

The soul of this robed priestess circles around the same thoughts in a pattern reminiscent of pacing.
"You still don't remember the spell?"
"Farewell."
"Didn't come this far just to tuck tail and surrender. Not to them." Unconcerned with you, her spirit persists in rapidly assessing the situation frozen in time.
[Give her the Memory of Magranite Incantations.] "I think this is what you're looking for."
"I... of course! Simple. How'd I forget a thing like that anyway?"
As she begins the incantation, you comprehend where and how the bomb was hidden.
Knowing this, it feels as if a thousand pairs of eyes are observing your progress at once. The illusion fades under their scrutiny.
"You've got to remember the incantation. Don't forget, don't let it go."
"Who are you?"
[Continue observing her.]
She doesn't seem to hear you.
"Waidwen's soul is in the bomb? This just got more complicated."
"You won't hear this, but I'll return your memory if I happen across it."

The mechanism was elegant in its simplicity. When a fragment of Waidwen reacted to his approach on the bridge above, it conducted soul energy into the copper and triggered the explosive.

A bomb for Waidwen made of Waidwen.
It was a delicate trigger by design. The work of removing such a critical part will involve no small risk.

"Can't think... why can't I think of it?" 

Her soul dims its luminosity to a speck, what you take to be the spiritual equivalent of a wince.
The soul of this priestess is muttering an incantation under her breath.
"Once I've got my senses back, I'll drag them all along for my fiery ride into Hel."
[Think of a spell, try and help her recall something.]
Her soul twitches, as if your intervention makes a small dent in her confusion, but it isn't enough to restore her memory.
"Ugh. Almost had it that time."
No sooner does the book make contact with her than it ceases to exist, absorbed into her memories. You feel the essence of the priestess swell with life and vigor.
"I memorized that illusion spell. How can it be gone? Another second and Waidwen will know the bomb is here. Damn it, girl, this is your chance..."
"The whole point of the thing is that his soul finds him first."

As you intuit her meaning, you catch a flash of memory:

Robed priests assembling a delicate mechanism - spiked copper plates housing a fragile shard of adra. 

The adra houses a piece of Waidwen's soul.
"Durance was right. The bomb worked because a part of Waidwen's soul was inside."
"You can't remember the spell to hide the bomb?"
"It's like I'm on stage and forgot the words of the song... how could this happen?" Her soul turns on itself in desperation.
